content.raw:
Hum, I'm not sure what you mean by the plane of wheels here. 

According to the universal joint [documentation](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/7298099ad5967af3b9207ae93ae309ee861fd31c/gazebo/physics/UniversalJoint.hh?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#UniversalJoint.hh-31), the first axis is attached to the parent (the chassis) and the second is attached to the child (the wheel). So the axis in which the wheels rotate forward and backwards is axis 2. Axis 1 is the steering axis, so even as the wheels spin, it is still vertical. Does that make sense?

And to make things more complicated, even though axis1 is attached to the parent, its initial state is defined in the child link frame. Take a look, the cart on the right is in the initial pose, and the one on the left has moved:

![universalcart.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/RMMxjX/images/2550497189-universalcart.png)

See how axis 1 is defined in the negative Y axis of the cylinder, but doesn't remain on the cylinder's -Y. It remains fixed to the chassis.
